title: christopher chope tory upskirting ban blocks fgm law
story: Sir Christopher Chope stepped in to block the proposed new law using arcane Commons rules.He provoked an instant backlash from fellow Tories as top ministers said he was wrong, pure and simple.And a leading anti-FGM campaigner condemned Sir Christopher, blasting: I have nothing but disgust for this man.Tory MP Zac Goldsmith proposed a change to child welfare laws which would have allowed courts to protect children at risk of FGM.The bill, backed by the Government, was intended to stop young kids being taken abroad by their parents to undergo the horric and permanently damaging procedure.But when it was announced in the Commons today, Sir Christopher shouted object - single-handedly stopping the law from going any further.Mr Goldsmith called his actions just appalling and rubbished claims the veteran MP is only concerned about proper scrutiny of legislation.Sajid Javid added: Very disappointed by this. FGM is child abuse. I am determined to stamp out this despicable and medieval practice.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: Outraged Chris Chope has blocked the FGM safeguarding bill in Parliament today. His actions are wrong, pure and simple.Anti-FGM campaigner Nimco Ali personally lobbied Sir Christopher to try and convince him not to block the bill.He refused - then accused her of verbal abuse and insult when she called him an embarrassment.She said this evening: I have nothing but disgust for this man.Sir Christopher rose to notoriety last year when he intervened to block a bill outlawing upskirting - when men take photos up womens skirts.His Commons office was festooned with underwear in protest.

title: weather forecast met office storm erik
story: The Met Office has issued a number of warnings ahead of Storm Erik bringing possible flooding and travel chaos in mph winds and rain.The Met Office is predicting severe gales first thing in the north on Saturday.Showers will also hit western and norther parts.Alex Deakin from the Met Office said: Sunday will see outbreaks of rain across England and Wales, could see some snow for a time over the hills, especially over northern England and Wales.One of the rain warnings says: There is a small chance that homes and businesses could be flooded, causing damage to some buildings.There is a small chance of fast flowing or deep floodwater causing danger to le.Tragically the wintry weather cost a man his le, after mph gale winds blew a huge tree onto his car as he drove.Witnesses rushed to lt heavy branches off two crushed cars in Buckfastleigh, Devon, this morning - as forecasters warn the chaotic weather brought by Storm Erik is set to worsen.And this afternoon people were pulled from a submerged car after it came off a flooded road.Two passersby raised the alarm and pulled the driver and passenger from the ford in St Clears, near Carmarthen.Today will see wet and windy weather affecting the whole of the UK, with gales set to become severe, as Scottish hills and Welsh mountains see snowfall.The wind will set in overnight with strong gales and heavy rain in the northwest, but with some clearer spells where.From Sunday to Tuesday the UK will see more sunshine and showers, but the south is set for fairly persistent rain.Wet and windy weather conditions are set to cause possible power cuts this weekend as coastal communities have been warned to be aware of large waves and spray.It comes as the Met Office issued a weather warnings for heavy rain in Scotland right through until Saturday afternoon.Met Office meteorologist Sarah Kent warned the stormy weather will result in some quite nasty travelling conditions.She said: Its going to be a noticeably windy day everywhere today.And that is going to be in association with outbreaks of heavy rain too, so there will be some quite nasty travelling conditions out there this morning.The forecast has warned of powerful gusts of  to mph inland and occasionally mph along exposed coasts.Winds are expected to finally ease off by Sunday.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: “A deep area of low pressure is expected to track across northern Britain later on Friday and through early Saturday.“Gales will become widespread later on Friday, persisting well into Saturday whilst becoming more westerly.”He added: “In addition, bands of heavy rain sweeping eastwards on Friday, in particular, will present an additional hazard.”Storm Erik was named by Irish forecaster Met Eireann on Thursday and overnight brought winds of mph to Cork.The unsettled weather over the next few days will come ahead of plunging temperatures next week.February  could be the coldest weather for NINE years as icy conditions .The wintry conditions are expected to continue into the half-term break from February .

title: meghan markle bananas used make cakes
story: The Duchess of Sussex scribbled phrases such as “You are brave” and “You are strong” as she helped prepare goody bags last week.She said she hoped they would help the women to “feel empowered”.Snaps of them were put on display at charity One’s Bristol HQ — but it has emerged the bananas were never handed out.Amy Sutclfe, who works with One, told The Sun there were “a limited number” and they were put in cakes because more women could have a share.Earlier she wrote in a blog: “The bananas may be gone but their message of love remains.”She added: “We’ve turned the bananas into cakes which have been given out through our ­services and the women have really valued this.”It was announced that heavily pregnant Meghan, , will visit Morocco with husband Prince Harry for two days later this month. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: libby squire new cctv footage
story: Separate film seen by The Sun shows a similar car driving up a nearby street minutes later.The footage begins seconds after midnight last Friday and shows a silver hatchback parked in Haworth Street, Hull.At .am a person opens the passenger door and gets in next to a driver. Police believe that person is second-year university student Libby. The car then drives up the street and out of view.A second film, obtained by The Sun from a shopkeeper, shows a similar car being driven along Newland Avenue, half a mile away,  minutes later, at .am.It shows a police car patrolling the same road  seconds before.Cops yesterday quizzed Polish butcher Pawel Relowicz, , over the two pieces of footage after they were granted a -hour extension to quiz him on abduction claims.Detectives will want to investigate whether the car in the footage is the Vauxhall Astra seized from suspect Relowicz.They obtained the CCTV last Sunday but kept it under wraps as they frantically pieced together the car’s movements before and after Libby disappeared.The Sun was aware of the crucial development before the arrest but agreed not to publish details.Shop owner and dad-of-two Mohammed Burhan, , told how his cameras picked up a car driving along Newlands Avenue the night Libby vanished.He told The Sun: “The police have been into all of the shops along here asking for CCTV footage over a particular timeframe.“They came into my shop and have taken the video from three of my cameras.“I hope my CCTV can in some way help the police find Libby and discover what has happened.”Libby was seen on the bench close to her home on Wellesley Avenue at .pm last Thursday.The Haworth Street footage was captured by cameras overlooking steel gates to an electrical firm.Staff checked it after Libby was reported missing and alerted cops.But workers there are fuming detectives took so long to reveal it.One said: “We couldn’t understand why it wasn’t published straight away by the police.“If it was my daughter I would have it everywhere.“Surely they have had enough time to examine it, obtain the licence plate and do checks to find out where it went.Time is of the essence. They always talk about the golden hour in investigations. They’ve had nearly a week.”Libby vanished after a night out with pals on Thursday January .They were turned away from a club because she was too drunk.Pals put her in a taxi to take her home and she was dropped off near her digs at around .pm.She was seen staggering in the street then sat on the bench a short time later. Police said the last time they can be sure she was in that area was .am.Cops swooped on the home that meat factory worker Relowicz shares with we Jagoda and their two kids at pm on Wednesday.Libby’s mum and dad, Lisa, , and Russ, , have travelled to Hull from their home in High Wycombe, Bucks.Senior cops insist they are still treating Libbys disappearance as a missing persons inquiry.Friends of Libby are praying for her . One, Rachel wrote: “Please just come home lib.”Another said: “I just want my best friend back.”Lisa has posted a heartfelt message on her Facebook, and changed her profile picture to one of Libby.She wrote: “One week without her”, with crying emojis.Lisa also thanked the public for their support. Pals have raised £, in less than a day for the family’s hotels and bills in Hull.Det Supt Matt Hutchinson yesterday confirmed police had been given extra time to quiz Relowicz.He said officers have viewed s of hours of CCTV footage.One line of inquiry is the possibility Relowicz was moonlighting as an unlicensed taxi driver.Lib Dem councillor Paul Drake-Davis said: “As long as police say there is hope we will keep that candle burning for Libby.”CCTV film captures a woman believed to be Libby Squire getting into a car — before being driven out of view.Footage taken just after midnight last Friday shows the vehicle already parked on Haworth Street in Hull.The driver s at .am, unlocks it and then sits facing out with the driver’s door open.He appears to roll a cigarette or type into a phone.A cyclist rides past and is followed seconds later by a car.After sitting for nearly three minutes the man stands up and walks away, locking the car.At .am the passenger side door is opened and a person believed to be Libby gets in.The man walks round the back of the car before getting into the driver’s seat and setting off.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: who is christopher chope and why did the tory mp block the fgm children act ammendment
story: Here’s what you need to know about Christopher Chope and why he is objecting to child protection proposals linked to female genital mutilation.The -year-old Sir Christopher was born in Putney and educated at Marlborough College and St Andrews University, where he studied law.After graduating he worked as a barrister and was first elected to Parliament as the MP for Christchurch in .He served as a minister in the governments of Margaret Thatcher and John Major and held shadow ministerial posts under William Hague and Michael Howard.Sir Christopher is a leading member of a group of backbench Conservatives who scrutinise legislation they feel to be well meaning but badly thought out, the BBC reportedTheir mission is to ensure such laws are not passed by a few MPs on a poorly attended Friday sitting, when many colleagues have already left for their constituencies.He insists on proper scrutiny, and he has spent most Commons Fridays for the last  years doing that.Under House of Commons procedures bills are presented for a second reading without debate - unless an MP shouts object.If they do then the proposed legislation has to be presented again.Sir Christopher objects on principle to legislation being passed without debate and, as he sees it, proper scrutiny at the second reading stage.On Friday he shouted object when the title of the Children Act  Bill was read out in the Common.The arcane procedure meant the bill could not proceed.The ammendment was intended to stop young kids being taken abroad by their parents to undergo the horric and permanently damaging procedure.Though the government backs the proposal its a been put forward by Tory backbencher Zac Goldsmith meaning it will struggle to find parliamentary time.Sir Christopher’s stance angered fellow MPs including many fellow Tories.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said he was outraged by Sir Christophers actions, saying they were wrong, pure and simple”.But responding to the criticism Sir Christopher said accused MPs of “indulging in virtue-signalling rather than looking at the substance”.He added: My constituents know what I am doing. We are having letters saying what is Parliamentary democracy all about  I object to Bills going through undebated at second reading.People are muddling up the substance of the matter. You could virtue signal. We could do all of our law by emotion rather than by debate.The MP rose to notoriety last year when he intervened to block a bill outlawing upskirting - when men take photos up womens skirts.His Commons office was festooned with underwear in protest.

title: teacher john teti creepy texts teen pupil grooming fly to france

Im so sick of this.Technology tutor Teti has been charged with “being an authority figure soliciting or engaging in a romantic relationship.”He was said to have been reprimanded last October over contacting pupils via education app Remind Me.This written counselling by the schools administration was in regards to maintaining a professional and ethical distance with his students,” Broward Sherf’s deputy Timothy Metz wrote in the affidavit.But Teti circumvented administrative monitoring and suspicion by swapping mobile phone numbers with several of his students and communicating with them for the rest of term.Teti appeared to be grooming the girl, building her trust by, among other allegations,” the document says.He is said to have told the teen over the phone that he was worried about statutory rape charges and that it was legal in France to marry at the age of .“Shedoesn’t have to know, we can fly to France,” he allegedly said.Teti intensied his pursuit and would routinely send her sexually charged text messages, often late at night.In one text he drew a heart with her name in it, the affidavit said.He was also said to have messaged the girl the next day saying he tried to stalk her coming out of class, but could not find her.I think youre just avoiding me because youre afraid thatyoure near me for too long, you wont be able to control yourself and just going to attempt to start making out with me, Teti allegedly wrote.He also said she was in love with him, but you just dont want to admit it.”In another text - after the girl told Teti she was sexually deprived” - he suggested she use alternatives, the court document says.He also reportedly confessed his love for her and extended his arms to hug her in front of her pal in school.And she was “overwhelmed” when he found her address and sent her a package of snacks and notes.Teti was arrested after the girl’s dad accused him of being a paedophile when his other kids tipped him off abut the teacher’s texts.The teacher was said to have dismissed the accusation by claiming the messages were “a joke.”And in a call recorded by her father he “discussed the size of his penis and lack of stamina during sex,” reports Local  News.An education spokeswoman said Teti was sacked and escorted from school by police.

title: theresa may brexit irish pm leo varadakar dublin backstop
story: The Prime Minister is this evening jetting to Dublin for a dinner date with the Taoiseach after her trip to Brussels yesterday.Shes expected to ask him for help in changing the Irish backstop plan which is preventing her Brexit deal being approved by MPs.But speaking on a trip to Belfast this afternoon, Mr Varadkar insisted Mrs May wont be able to drive a wedge between Brussels and the Irish government.He said: I am the EU when it comes to this matter.The Irish government and the EU are all one when it comes to Brexit and Im sure people,they havent realised that over the past two years, theyre coming to realise it.The decision that weve made as an EU is that the withdrawal agreement and the backstop are not up for negotiation but we can talk about the joint Political Declaration and what changes might be made to that.He added: Today is not a day for negotiations, today is a day for us to share our perspectives and for us to listen to each other.I believe ultimately we are going to have to get this deal over the line and I am determined to do that, and I think any engagement with the British Prime Minister and her team is useful.During his visit to Belfast, Mr Varadkar met with Northern Irish politicians including the DUP.Unionist boss Arlene Foster said they had had a positive meeting and rubbished claims that Brexit may have to be delayed.Tonight Mrs May will tell Mr Varadkar that after last weeks Commons vote approving the deal as long as the backstop is fixed, a legally binding change is the only way to avoid No Deal.She will be accompanied by Attorney Geoffrey Cox, seen as a key figure because of his influence with Brexiteers who need to be assured that any fix is legally sound.Mr Varadkar is coming under increasing pressure to sign off on changes to the backstop, which is designed to avoid a hard border.Brexiteers say the backstop in its current form risks leaving Britain trapped in the EUs customs union indefinitely.Angela Merkel is understood to be lobbying Dublin not to block a legally binding fix to the proposal.But Mr Varadkar is also under pressure at home - as a new poll finds four-fths of Irish voters want him to hold firm.Hes likely to be crucial to the process because EU leaders are wary of approving any Brexit deal that doesnt command support in Ireland.Yesterday Mrs May held frosty talks with European leaders Jean-Claude Juncker and Donald Tusk.It came after Mr Tusk said theres a special place in hell for the politicians who led the Brexit campaign.But the PM won a breakthrough as the EU agreed to restart talks on the deal with the aim of fixing the backstop.Mrs Merkel said yesterday: I think we can find solutions without re-opening the withdrawal agreement.Hardline Brexiteers insist they wont back the withdrawal agreement unless the backstop is removed entirely.But Mrs May is confident she can win over enough MPs to pass a deal by providing legally binding assurances that the backstop wont be in place permanentlyit ever does come into effect.Jeremy Corbyn this week launched a bid to force a soft Brexit, pledging to back Mrs Mays dealshe signs Britain up to the customs union.

title: brexit delay local election wipe out
story: The ongoing deadlock with the EU has led many to expect the Article  exit talks will have to be extended beyond the March  deadline.But local government bosses and Cabinet ministers have warned No as well as the Tory party’s chairman that its vote at the council polls on May  will be decimatedthey are seen to have broken the key Brexit promise.That gives the PM just a five week extra window to wrap up Brexit and pass all necessary new laws, and  weeks in total from now.The Conservatives most senior councillor, Lord Porter – who chairs the Local Government Association, told The Sun: “If we’re not out by the time of the elections, we’re going to get kicked.It won’t be good for us.“It will also hit turnout, as people will be put off politics altogether.“Brandon Lewis has been made very aware of this.”A Cabinet minister also warned about the dire consequences of delaying Brexit beyond July , which would mean the UK would almost certainly be forced to hold fresh MEP elections along with the rest of Europe.The senior minister told The Sun: “The new European Parliament takes it seats on July , sowe’re not out by then we’ll have to blow £m on holding new elections here for it.“Our councillors are telling us that voters would punish us hard at the ballot box in May for this.So extending that long is untenable.”During meetings in Brussels on Thursday, it emerged Mrs May told EU chiefs she would not ask to extend Article , despite the fast approaching exit deadline.This year’s local elections are being held almost everywhere across England, outside of London.A total of  English local councils are up for grabs, as well as six directly elected mayors in England, and all  local councils in Northern Ireland.Almost all were last contested in  on the same day as the General Election, which David Cameron’s Tories won.Successor LordKerslake said Britain is heading for years of wrangling with Brussels.The new warnings came as former top mandarin Lord O’Donnell became the latest senior figure to urge the Brexit deadline be extended.The former Cabinet Secretary to three Prime Ministers between  and  wrote in the Evening Standard: “Are we going to follow a Norwegian model or one from Singapore, Turkey, Switzerland or Albania “The truth is we do not know and it is, I am afraid to say, irresponsible for any government to even contemplate embarking on such a perilous journey as Brexit without giving us a clearer idea of the eventual destination.”Next week the Commons could back a motion drawn up by senior Labour MP Yvette Cooper to delay Britain’s leaving datewe’re heading for No Deal.But evenMPs do vote for the controversial amendment, every single EU country would have the right to veto it.French officials have warned that they won’t approve a delay unless the UK has a coherent plan to use the extra time.A source told Reuters: “Fundamentally, we oppose an extension without a plan. That’s clear. We won’t accept it.”The official added that a delay would only be acceptableBritain wanted time “to build a new political solution”.Where are the radical plans to sort the housing crisis, or soaring crime  Or to lower taxes, as Tories always should New NHS cash aside, what can Theresa May’s Government boast about after nearly three years of Brexit paralysis Its unhinged war on our sugar intake Its scandalous suffocation at birth of the fracking industry  Sneaking through new taxes on the dead The Tories need a brand new offer to voters, and fast. BecauseBrexit is ever sorted, they will suddenly require answers to Corbyn’s armoury of policies.Most of those are ruinous throwbacks to the s. But every day they are out there unchallenged, they gain traction.To some voters any plan — even from Marxist extremists — is more enticing than a listless Government bereft of ideas.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: danny dyer right royal family flaw
story: A documentary that was as funny as it was surprising, and all the more so because the BBC did the right thing and played it absolutely straight.Genuine blue plaque television, in fact, that should never have been revisited or reformatted, not least because it would remind the Beeb that Danny’s wonderful everyman story had killed the whole WDYTYA franchise.So I’d been expecting this sucker punch, ever since its final credits rolled in .Danny Dyer’s Right Royal Family, on BBC. “A potty old adventure,” as his nibs described it, tracing Danny’s family line even further back, to Scandinavia’s King Rollo, his -times great grandfather, who I’d always assumed was a s children’s cartoon character, rather than a ninth-century Viking warrior.There were two episodes of it this time as well, which I know some of you thought were as funny as the original. Personally, I didn’t.What I hope we’re all agreed on, though, is the fact that Danny’s too busy playing Danny Dyer, the professional geezer, to be a good listener or natural TV historian.It’s an act that worked, of course, when he was wondering, “Eleanor of Aquitaine, was she a looker ” but didn’t serve him so well when presented with a longbow.“Long, innit ”The Beeb clocked this before production started, obviously, so had paired him up with dozens of head-patting historians and actors who got him to dress up as every kind of medieval t**t you can imagine. Like Mr Benn on crack, it was.Armour, codpieces, nappies, tights, doublet and hose, and a gigantic white smock, bleached with human urine, which had one grovelling “courtier” wondering: “Has all the p*** been washed out, my Lord King ”A good question.We didn’t actually get the answer, though, until part two, on Wednesday, when, after a brief detour round his ancestors, Louis IX of France, William the Conqueror and Henry II, viewers got to the nub of things, with Professor Chris Given-Wilson explaining the agonising death of Edward II: “By thrusting a hollow instrument, like the end of a trumpet, up his fundament.”“’Old on a minute,” said a rattled Danny. “He’s been stabbed  With a trumpet ”“Into his fundament.” Long pause.“Don’t tell me it’s up his a**e ”Right up it, Danny, with a red-hot poker. News which didn’t just do his “nut in”, it seemed to derail the entire documentary.They ran out of direct royal ancestors shortly afterwards as well, and the BBC adopted its stupid default setting in such circumstances. It turned Danny’s Right Royal Family into a dance and cookery show, complete with demonstrations of both, from medieval experts.It was about this time I also sussed out what was going on in the background, with all those winsome historians. An audition.The BBC was using it to find its new face of history, though why any of the blokes turned up is a mystery. Auntie’s already made it clear: “The days of white, middle-aged men explaining stuff are over.”Danny, on the other hand, can be tolerated, because he’s their new performing Cockney. A novelty act who can be dressed up and patronised so much he ended this one doing some weird medieval can-can, with his family, in front of his lost ancestral pile.A trumpet wasn’t quite shoved up his fundament as they danced, but the p*** had very much been washed out of him, my Lord King.GREAT TV lies and delusions of the month. “I think it’s going to be a really great show.” Cheryl Tweedy, The Greatest Dancer.“We do TV shows and we’re national treasures.” Jedward, Celebrity Coach Trip.“People will remember my name and I love that.” Some t**t off Ship- wrecked.IF you’re to take anything from the news experts have claimed Monday, January  was the most depressing day of the year, it’s probably the fact the experts clearly never sat through what happened eight days later, on Tuesday, January .Britain’s Top  Dogs Live: . All two-and-a-half yapping hours of it, on ITV, with a bad hangover, in the company of presenters Ben Fogle and Sara Cox.A test beyond personal endurance not because of the alcohol or dogs, who are a largely blameless lot, but the presence of their barmy owners, who attribute all sorts of superpowers to their dumb little mutts and blur the human animal relationship way beyond the point of reason and sometimes even good taste.Hits Radio DJ Gemma Atkinson, for instance, claimed: “I wouldn’t be where I am today without Norman”, her pet sproodle.Which is a hell of a guilt trip to pin on any dog.While Spandau Ballet’s Martin Kemp was seen, sitting alongside Popsie the poodle and his Wham! backing-singer we Shirlie, exclaiming: “I’ll say this for her,she does do a poo she goes into the spare bathroom.”The least you’d expect, frankly, after  years of marriage.The case study that really finished me off, though, was a dog dancing instructor called Joan Clark and her powder puff hounds, whose act, as described by Sara Cox, was: “All building up to the big finish. Can she pull it off  Joan points to the spot and it’s one, two, three pups between her legs.”CHANNEL ’s Pure is a comedy drama about a woman who suffers from the sixth sense of seeing naked people and is so tormented by her condition she screams: “F***ing stop. Make it stop.”So she can read minds as well.QUIZ show doughballs of the week. The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Real Madrid play their home football matches in which Spanish city ”John: “Barcelona.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman Emperor Augustus ”Jorge: “July.”Ben Shephard: “Hajduk Split are a football team from which eastern European country ”Jenner: “Japan.”And Joe Lycett: “In his song Le On Mars, David Bowie wonderedthere was le on which planet ”Amber: “Jupiter.” Andy Murray texting Good Morning Britain with the :am request: “Please stop discussing my genitals on national television.”Andrew Neil ripping all of Ken Livingstone’s socialist fantasies about Venezuela into tiny shreds, on This Week.And The Time It Takes answer contestant John gave to the question: “The metaphorical breaking of which body part brings good luck to an actor ” “Neck.” A thought that’s occurred to me every time I watch the Baftas.FAIR play, I thought, to Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair. They really seemed to have all the important ITV advertising bases covered.First thing in the morning they’re dropping regular hints about “bothersome vaginas” during Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain sht. Then there they were again, on Sunday night, directly before Gemma Collins skated at Dancing On Ice.Although, I say “skated,” you’d see marginally more movement from the Larsen C ice shelf in Antarctica than we got from Gemma on this week’s show.The heroic Matt Evers had to shove, heave, prod and generally wield her like a hypermarket shopping trolley, in fact, just to get Gemma turning on her axis.One very calculated burst of tears later, though, the mug punters had voted her through for yet another week and she’d parked her over-entitled backside on Piers Morgan’s sofa early yesterday morning.So where the hell was Vagisan feminine itching cream and Jenny Eclair when the occasion really called for them Asleep on the job, that’s where. story: NewsBBC Question Time investigating after same man gets in audience multiple timesSNP backers were angry after the man launched a tirade against the party on the show in MotherwellShareCommentsByPaul RodgerDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video ukip-mans-third-appearance-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBBC Question Time has said it is investigating after the same man got into the audience multiple times. SNP backers were outraged after the man - named online as an ex-UKIP council candidate, Billy Mitchell - launched a tirade against the party on the show in Motherwell last night. They quickly said hed appeared on the show repeatedly wearing the same orange jacket - and even been called for multiple questions. Applicants to the Question Time audience are asked to spell out any previous times theyve been on the show. Guests must also reveal who they would be most likely to vote for in a General Election, how they voted in the EU referendum, and whether they are a member of a political party. BBC sources admitted there was no hard and fast cap on the number of times someone can appear in the audience.   But they insisted they try to allow as many people as possible to join the programme and select audiences who are local and have a broad range of views. A BBC spokesperson said tonight: “We are investigating this issue.” The man was selected from the audience to speak, and accused the SNP of being hypocritical in criticising Theresa May and the Conservative Partys handling of Brexit . He criticised  member Fiona Hyslop, SNP Cabinet Secretary for Culture, Tourism and External Affairs over Brexit. Launching a tirade against the MSP for Linlithgow said: What are you criticising Brexit about  You are so guilty, hypocritical about the indyref - there was no deal. You had no deal, you had no currency, you told us oil was going to be a million pound a barrel. Now you can get a barrel for a tenner down the Barras. No deal, no plan, absolutely useless.  Former SNP MP John Nicolson complained it was a recurring troll who had been invited on again. I get it that he sneaked back once, maybe twice. But again  he complained. I know it’s tough to screen the audience with a small team. But there’s something awry with audience booking that he keeps getting through screening. He’s a politician masquerading as a punter. Facebook user Peter Clive said: They should just stick him on the  the next time theyre in Scotland: hes practically the Scottish Farage now, thanks to the exposure they give him. Twitter users also questioned the former UKIP candidates reappearance on the show. User Eileeneileen said: His incoherent rant shouldn’t have been allowed to go on for as long as it did. While Burdynumnum wrote on Twitter: He’s been on three times, had his question picked each time and been tweeted by a BBC twitter account. Now what are the chances  Asked for comment by the Mirror, Mr Mitchell said: “A politician  Erm no Im a normal member of the public whos opinion doesnt match the mob,I was for SNP they would love me and you wouldnt be asking me why I gave an opinion that dfers. Im not linked or member of any political party nor am I a member of the Orange Order or flute band peoples imaginations love to run wild when they want to destroy your character.” Asked how many times he’d been on Question Time he said: “Haha now that is a story. No comment Im enjoying seeing all the folk argue with each other and all the wild assumptions. But it will be the last that I can tell you.” He added: “Listen I’m just a normal person interested in politics but because I dont support independence Im evil its not true I just dont think its good for Scotland.”

title: christopher chope branded appalling tory
story: NewsChristopher Chope branded a disgrace as Tory MP blocks progress of anti-FGM lawThe law protecting young girls from Female Genital Mutilation remains on the back burner after the Tory MP shouted "object" - just like he did for an upskirting BillShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video christopher-chope-branded-appalling-tory-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Tory MP has been branded an disgrace and a dinosaur after holding up a law to protect young girls from Female Genital Mutilation. Sir Christopher Chope shouted object to the law clearing a key hurdle without debate - the same tactic he used for a law against upskirting last year. He was branded appalling by fellow Tory MP Zac Goldsmith, who had been steering the Children Act Bill through the Commons, as Tory chiefs faced calls to strip him of the party whip. Home Secretary Sajid Javid blasted: Very disappointed by this. FGM is child abuse. I am determined to stamp out this despicable and medieval practice. We will do all we can protect girls at risk. Health Secretary Matt Hancock tweeted: Outraged Chris Chope has blocked the FGM safeguarding Bill in Parliament today. His actions are wrong, pure  simple.Dawn Butler, Labour’s Shadow Minister for Women and Equalities, said: Its unacceptable that this dinosaur of a Tory MP consistently gets away with blocking new laws which would protect the safety and rights of women.“This makes it even more shocking that he was given a knighthood by Theresa May last year.“Christopher Chope is causing shame and embarrassment on the Tories but also for the country and its time for the Tories to show they really care about these issues by stripping him of the whip. Furious anti-FGM campaigner Nimco Ali said he was an embarrassment to his party and humanity. She tweeted: He needs his whip and knighthood removed. The backbench Bill would make it easier for judges to step in and place child victims of the practice in care - taking them away from their parents.The Bill was fully approved by the House of Lords in November - but because it is not proposed by the government, receives only limited debating time in the Commons. Despite not being debated today, it could have passed its second reading without debateMPs had chosen to do so. It would have still been scrutinised by MPs in a y committee stage before ing for a final vote. But because Sir Christopher shouted object, it will remain on the back burner. It has next been listed for March  but could potentially be blocked then.   The MP previously faced a furious backlash when he shouted object to a law making upskirting a specic criminal offence. Anonymous Parliamentary workers adorned his office door with womens underwear and the law was eventually passed in another form after Cabinet ministers intervened. Sir Christopher has previously said he is not against the inidual laws, and is simply making the point that laws should not be passed without proper debate. But Mr Goldsmith today said he had only chosen to shout object to some laws - and not others by his friends.  Mr Goldsmith tweeted before the incident today: Today Chris Chope MP will once again use arcane procedure to block a Bill that would amend the  Children Act to include FGM on the list of thingsfor which the courts can issue protection ordersthey think a child is at risk. The Bill has been scrutinised fully in the Lords, and is supported now by Government. Chope has been begged not to block it by FGM campaigners.People ask why he would do such a thing - and indeed why he has similarly blocked motions to debate Hillsborough, pardon Alan Turing, ban the use of wild animals in circuses, target ‘upskirting’ and much much more besides.  His argument is that he simply wants Bills properly debated. But it is a pretence.If today’s Bill goes through, we will have Committee Stage, Report Stage and Third Reading – all of which involve scrutiny and debate. If it is blocked, there is no debate. Labour shadow culture minister Rosena Allin-Khan demanded Tory chairman Brandon Lewis reprimand the MP. Lib Dem MP Tom Brake said Sir Christopher had reached a new low, adding: Absolutely appalling behaviour. He is a disgrace to parliament, his constituency and women  children everywhere. Labour MP Luke Pollard added: Christopher Chope objects to an anti-FGM measure and brings the whole place into disrepute. How is he able to get away with this  Sir Christopher did not immediately respond to requests for comment by the Mirror. However, in tests to Ms Ali shown to BuzzFeed News he said: This should be fully debated.

story: NewsAlfie Lamb seen running after mum on CCTV hours before he was crushed to deathAdrian Hoare and Stephen Waterson are on trial after Alfie Lamb, three, was crushed behind an Audis electric car seatShareByBradley Jolly:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video alfie-lamb-mum-boyfriend-cctv-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCCTV shows Alfie Lamb on a shopping trip with his family hours before he was crushed to death with an electric car seat. The three-year-olds mother Adrian Hoare and her boyfriend Stephen Waterson are on trial accused of child cruelty and manslaughter over Alfies death. He was crushed behind an Audi convertibles electric car seat on the way home from a shopping trip in Croydon, south London, on February  last year. The CCTV, today shown to a jury at the Old Bailey, shows three-foot Alfie with Hoare, , and her -year-old partner, the adopted son of former Tory minister Nigel Waterson. Cross-examining the mum, prosecutor Duncan Atkinson QC said: Whose pace are you walking at  What allowances were you making for Alfies little legs  Why is Alfie having to run   The defendant replied: Its just the way I walk evenits just me and Alfie. Alfie always runs. Mr Atkinson QC went on: Until he got into that car on the way back from Sutton, he was fine wasnt he  And by the time that the car reached Adams Way he was very far from fine, wasnt he  Something had to have happened in that journey  So when doctors and police start saying something happened to Alfie, you knew it had to have happened in the car. Were you not thinking it must have been Stephen   Hoare, originally from Gravesend, Kent, replied: Not straight away. Mr Atkinson QC said: What Stephen had done with his seat he had done deliberately. He was annoyed the second time he moved his chair back  Hoare agreed, but added: To begin with I did not blame anyone for what happened. The lawyer said: Was it your relationship with Stephen was just too important  Wasnt the reality you just put what Stephen wanted first  The defendant denied this.  The trial had earlier heard how Waterson allegedly said: I will not be told what to do by a three-year-old, before allegedly crushing the boy. There were four adults in the car as well as two children who were forced to sit in the footwell at the time. Tana Adkin QC, defending Waterson, said his chair had nothing to do with the youngsters injuries. She suggested Hoare must have done something.  Hoare denies manslaughter, child cruelty and common assault on Emilie Williams, who was also in the car. Waterson, of Croydon, has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter and intimidation of the driver Marcus Lamb. The couple and Williams have pleaded guilty to conspiring to pervert the course of justice by making  statements to police.

title: brian reade twisted words starved
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: Twisted words and starved of benefits... welcome to real hellThis country has been locked in a state of arrested ­development for the past three years as all political energy has been spent on failing to deliver an imaginary freedom from invented tyrantsShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  FEB Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video mirroronthestreet-campaign-tent-city-leeds-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIve never been to hell although I have stood in a Zara s queue for an hour. It’s not a place I want to visit, shyespecially now Donald Tusk assures us it could soon be home to the likes of Nigel Farage, Jacob Rees-Mogg and Michael Gove. Imagine the dficulty in choosing which one to withhold your pee fromthey were all on fire  Of course, the Eurocrat’s damning words about the people who “promoted Brexit without even a sketch of a plan how to carry it out safely” have been twisted to make it sound like he wants to give a one-way ticket to Satanville to all . million leave voters. But there’s nothing new in that. Twisted words, half-truths and outright lies are the weapons that have kept this country locked in a state of arrestedshy development for the past three years as all political energy has been spent on failing to deliver an imaginary freedom from invented tyrants.   Meanwhile, the issues that affect the lives of the vast majority living in the real world are ignored, leaving the weakest to go to the wall. Hence the mass use of foodbanks becoming an acceptable part of le in the world’s sixth biggest economy. Who could have read The Mirror’s shock report on homelessness across Britain without feeling immensely saddened and angry  I was one of  reporters who spoke to some of the thousands of people forced to live on our freezing streets every night. The reasons behind their soaring numbers are complex but the scourge is beatable. And surely every rich and civilised country wants it beaten  But what happens when your country is made poorer and less civilised due to devoting its resources to solving one political party’s insoluble dilemma  On Wednesday, the Commons rose at .pm instead of the usual .pm due to MPs running out of things to debate. As Shadow Commons Leader, Valerie Vaz, said: “This shyGovernment has no vision, no new ideas and crucially no legislation to fill the parliamentary timetable.” In the past three months alone, the Cabinet Office has handed pound. million to outside consultancy firms helping them with Brexit. How many people could that have taken off our streets    Most local councils are doing their best to meet the homeless crisis head-on, but when your funding from Westminster has been decimated it’s left to volunteers, charities and the goodwill of the public to take up the slack. Who could have failed to be angry looking at the photo of the skeletal -year-old Stephen Smith, who, despite having multiple shydebilitating illnesses, weighing six stone, and barely able to walk, was denied benefits by this Government and deemed fit for work.   It was only when he went for free advice at the CASA community centre in Liverpool, where volunteer advisers appealed and won his case, that he received the benefits that kept him alive. There was a typically rabid response from the right in this country to Tusk’s remarks about those who sold Brexit without a trace of a plan deserving a place in hell. But many of us agree with him. Because they are the dangerous ideologues behind the three years of political paralysis that has made le hell for those who least deserve it.

title: devastated owners pictures beloved dog
story: NewsDevastated owners pictures of beloved dog losing fight for le after eating browniesKate Chacksfield, , from Acton, West London, did everything she could to save pet Ruby - including spending £, - but she died days after consuming the brownies which contained XylitolShareCommentsByNiamh Shackleton:,  FEB NewsRuby, a Hungarian Vizsla, from Acton, West London, died after eating chocolate brownies "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dog owner has released tear-jerking photos of her beloved pet on le support - eight days before she died from eating chocolate brownies. Ruby - a Hungarian Vizsla - had cheekily stolen two brownies which contained Xylitol, a form of sweetener, which is toxic to dogs and can cause liver failure when consumed. Ruby fell ill within  hours leaving owner Kate Chacksfield, from Acton, West London, heartbroken.And despite spending pound, in a bid to save her le, Ruby died aged seven on October . Kate, , is now sharing her story to raise awareness for the dangers of dogs consuming natural sweeteners. The media and presentation coach said: I only made brownies with Xylitol in to reduce the amount of sugar I was eating. But while I was out, Ruby managed to get into the container off the side in the kitchen and eaten a couple.  She seemed fine at first and it wasnt until a couple of days later she began being violently ill and I took her to the vets. I had no idea how serious eating natural sweeteners was for dogs, the photos of her on le support still make me cry. Weve had her since she was a puppy and Im completely lost without her. Kate claims Ruby had stolen the chocolate brownies in the past and claims the vet had stated small amounts of chocolate arent too harmful to dogs her size. Following previous experiences - Kate wasnt too worried about Ruby this time until she began being sick. Kate said: Ruby began being violently sick so I rushed her to the vets so sent her home after checking her over.  But soon after she collapsed and we took her back as soon as possible - it was then they started treating her for rat poison because of her symptoms. We just thought she may have eaten some by mistake in the park or something - it never crossed my mind to mention the brownies. As Rubys condition began to deteriorate, she was taken to The Royal Veterinary College, London, but sadly died eight days later of liver failure and a suspected stroke. It wasnt until after Rubys death that vets askedshe may have consumed Xylitol which is when Kate realised her health deterioration was linked to the brownies. She said: I had absolutely no idea Xylitol was harmful to dogs what so ever and I was heartbroken when they told me and I knew it was too late for Ruby.  I really, really urge other dog owners to read up on the dangers of Xylitol in dogs and urgently take their pets to the vetthey accidentally consume it as it could be the dference between le and death. Xylitol sweetener can be found in many products such as sugar free sweets and gum, some baking mixes, peanut butters and chocolate. Kate says it takes just a quarter of a teaspoon to cause liver failure in dogs the size of a Labrador, and even less in smaller breeds. She said: We did everything we could to save Ruby - she was so loved and we all miss her dearly. We really had hope she would pull through so we were heartbroken when she didnt.  Wed love to be able to save other dogs from going through what Ruby went through by raising awareness on the dangers of Xylitol for dogs. It takes just a quarter of a teaspoon of sweetener to harm a dog. If anyone has any concerns they can the Animal PoisonLine for advice.

story: NewsDoctors gave me a month to live when I got married -  years later Im cancer free and pregnantEXCLUSIVE: Jo Kelly is now also expecting a baby after a stem cell transplant gave her the chance to give birthShareCommentsByWarren MangerFeatures Writer:,  FEB NewsJo with her husband Pete Ames - but doctors didnt give Jo a fighting chance when she was battling blood cancer"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith weeks left to live, Jo Kelly knew that shymarrying the man who adored her was the last gt of love she would give. She and Pete Ames had only been dating for six months but both knew they had found “the one”. Then doctors said they were running out of ways to treat the blood cancer she’d been fighting for three years. And she would probably die within months. “I was told I was out of treatment options,” says Jo. “All the doctors could offer me was palliative care. “I pushed them for a timeframe and they told me it was unlikely I’d make it past Christmas. It was devastating. I wouldn’t reach my one-year anniversary with Pete.  “A few weeks later we were painting my bedroom and Pete burst into tears. He told me he didn’t want me to leave this world not being his we.” So the couple planned their big day in eight weeks and wed in an emotional ceremony surrounded by their family. Eight years on, there is about to be a new addition to the Kelly-Ames family – a daughter for Pete and Jo, both . Against near-impossible odds, Jo beat her terminal cancer after doctors fought for pioneering drugs that kept her alive long enough for a stem cell transplant. Blood cancer charity Anthony Nolan then found the only registered donor in the world who was a genetic match.   Now Jo and Pete – who had beaten testicular cancer before they met – will welcome their baby girl later this month. Jo says: “We feel so lucky to be shyplanning for a future we never thought we had. I wrote a thank-you letter to my donor but didn’t hear back. All I know is he was  and I think he had dark hair. Every time I read that letter I cry. “We will write when our daughter arrives. We owe him everything – I wouldn’t be here without him.” Jo, of Lichfield, Staffs, who works for the Arts Council, was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s lymphoma at , after a large lump appeared on her neck. The disease can usually be cured with intensive chemotherapy and Jo gave up her job and moved in with her parents to focus on the treatment.  But she relapsed months later and over the next three years tried all shyavailable treatments. Nothing worked... Instead, the cancer spread to her lungs and bones. The pain was so severe Jo began suffering fits. She says: “When I was diagnosed, I felt like broken goods. I was a year out of university, embarking on my career and dating. I met Pete through a mutual friend, who told each of us what the other had been through. “We really clicked. He got everything. We knew this was something special. But our hopes were dashed when the doctors said they’d run out of options.” Pete proposed at his house, which he shydecorated with fairy lights. He even painted “I love you” on the walls in  languages. He quit his job in Birmingham to work for minimum wage in Manchester to be with Jo.  They hastily planned a wedding – finding an off-the-rack dress as they had no time to get one made. Jo says: “I was very frail, according to the doctors’ estimates I only had a month left. I had an IV drip I had to tape to the underside of my arm but it was an incredible day.” Pete says: “I’ve been to a lot of weddings but never one where there was so much love. Everyone was hugging each other.” Days before the wedding, Christie Cancer Hospital in Manchester told Jo her doctors had been given permission to give her a new drug, Brentuximab Vedotin, on compassionate grounds. It stopped the cancer progressing so well the NHS agreed to fund it for other patients, including  who went into remission and had le-saving stem cell transplants. Another drug Bendamustine, which is still not widely available on the NHS, sent Jo’s cancer into remission and she was able to have a transplant.  Jo says: “A year before my transplant we checked the donor register and there were no matches. By the time I was ready there was one. “We were terried he might not want to go through with it. We couldn’t speak to him directly but, thanks to Anthony Nolan, everything fell into place.” Jo spent a month in hospital during the London Olympics in  as her body was blasted with chemotherapy to wipe away the cancer, her bone marrow and her white blood cells to try to stop her body rejecting the transplant. Pete, a business consultant, says: “The worst moments were sitting at home after leaving Jo at the hospital, eating dinner at pm and thinking, ‘If the transplant doesn’t work, this is what’s left. Our bed felt so empty. There were a lot of tears.” The nightmare nearly became a reality... Jo says: “You are pushed very close to death during the transplant. You are being sustained by blood transfusions. There was one night where I felt something give way in my body. I hit rock bottom. I knewI chose, I could pass away quietly. But underneath that was another thought, ‘No, push through one more night.’ I had to keep trying for Pete and my parents. The next day my blood counts started to rise ever so slowly.” Recovery was tough. Jo suffered graft versus host disease, which can be fatal, as her body struggled to accept the transplant. It was  months before she was able toto regular work for the first time in five years. She took up track cycling and, after doctors gave her the all-clear, she ran the London Marathon on her rd birthday last April. The couple also discovered it might be possible for them to have a baby, despite Jo being left infertile by chemotherapy, as her womb was undamaged. They used Pete’s sperm and a donor egg but were left with just one embryo to implant. Jo says: “One of our friends said they thought it would work because we do pretty well when the odds are against us. “After years of having no future to plan for, we’re planning how to raise our daughter. She is the best gt – the gt of love we thought we’d never have.”Find out more about the Anthony Nolan charity at www.anthony nolan.org

title: family demand action after girl
story: NewsFamily demand action after girl, , found hanged in "chaotic" care psychiatric facilitySophie Bennett was found in a bathroom in Lancaster Lodge in Richmond, west LondonShareCommentsByTess de la Mare:,  FEB NewsSophie Bennett took her own le in May  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe family of a teenager found hanged at a psychiatric care facility deemed chaotic and unsafe by inspectors have called for criminal charges. Sophie Bennett, , was found in a bathroom in Lancaster Lodge in Richmond, west London, in May  just over a year after she was admitted in April . She died two days later in Kingston Hospital as a result of her injuries. The teenager suffered from bipolar affective disorder, social anxiety disorder and atypical autism. Shortly before Ms Bennett died, the Care Quality Commission criticised the facility as inadequate in a number of areas. At an inquest, jurors were tasked with deciding whether changes at the facility run by charity Richmond Psychosocial Foundation Internationalcontributed to her death. The home had seen a number of staff changes and was in the hands of interim manager Duncan Lawrence.  West London Coroners Court heard Mr Lawrence did not have a legitimate medical doctorate, and had instead obtained a certicate from a degree mill in Denmark. Mr Lawrence failed to attend the inquest despite being summonsed. It also emerged that Ms Bennett had self-harmed in April  and said she was experiencing suicidal thoughts, but staff at Lancaster Lodge had ignored advice to admit her straight to hospital for an assessment.  Instead, they decided to keep her in the home under close observation, but allowed her to close the bathroom door on the day she was found hanged. CQC inspector Wynne Price-Rees found staff and patients were happy when he visited for a routine inspection in the previous September. But he discovered a totally dferent story in March, adding: I think it was chaotic. On the first day of the urgent four-day inspection, he said he found Mr Lawrence disengaged and lacking knowledge of essential care documents.  Hedidnt seem to have a grasp of the concepts that are fundamental, Mr Price-Rees added. The inspector said he had numerous concerns, including kitchen items not being locked away and poorly qualied junior staff. In their conclusion on Thursday, the jury found that the changes to care, inadequately trained staff and the fact that staff were in the deep end and learning on the job all contributed to Ms Bennetts death. The jury found that a grossly inadequate observation plan was put in place for Ms Bennett, and not understood or followed.  They also said staff were not properly trained in carrying out room searches and did not know what items they should be looking for. Ben Bennett, Ms Bennetts father, also raised concerns about Elly Jansen, who was acting as a consultant to the RPFI board. Mr Bennett described Ms Jansen as possessing an extraordinary approach to management, which was like something out of the th century. It emerged that Ms Jansen was forced to step away from a psychiatric charity in the s due to allegations of financial mismanagement and misappropriated funds. Lawyers for the Bennett family allege that while not a trustee, Ms Jansen was effectively the shadow director of RPFI and the controlling mind, making decisions on staffing and management at Lancaster Lodge.  The inquest revealed several other residents at Lancaster Lodge became very ill amid the disruptions in  and at least one attempted suicide . Friend and fellow patient Clarissa Jeffrey said the changes in  made it feel like the residents were running the house. The changes felt like they were fuelled by trying to ... save money rather than trying to help the people in the lodge, she said in a statement to the inquest. Sophie told her mother Nickie Bennett the new regime saw the place become like a boot camp with strict rules and exercise, the court heard.  In a statement, Sophies family said: Weve waited nearly three years to find the truth about what happened to our beautul daughter who, despite her many problems, had a fulfilling le ahead of her. We thank the jury for listening to the, at times, dficult evidence, and their clear conclusions which vindicate our concerns. The family said it hoped the CQC would pursue a criminal prosecution and criticised the Charity Commission for failing to attend the inquest. [The Charity Commission] has known about the issues surrounding the governance of RPFI since well before Sophies death. I hope that it will now apply the full force of its powers to take action against those trustees who have clearly been negligent in their responsibilities. On Friday, coroner John Taylor said he would now prepare a Prevention of Future Deathsreport to be submitted to the RPFI board, the CQC, Charity Commission and other interested parties to prevent future tragedies arising from poor care. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

title: gravediggers strike helped put final
story: NewsGravediggers strike that helped put the final nail in the coffin of union powerDuring Labours winter of discontent, striking gravediggers were demonised in headlines flashed around the worldShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsIan Lowes was the gravediggers’ GMB convenor at the time "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey were condemned from the pulpit, denounced in Parliament and vilied in the media for not going to work. Their job was to dig graves and operate the crematorium for the people of Liverpool. But for  anxious days, they were on strike in the Winter of Discontent that paralysed the nation and cost Labour political power in . The gravediggers’ walkout was demonised in headlines like “Now They Won’t Let Us Bury Our Dead!”. Families were split and violence flared on Merseyside in the dispute – merely a microcosm of a national confrontation between Labour premier “Sunny Jim” Callaghan and the labour movement. Such was the furore that  years later, survivors of the industrial action cannot bring themselves to talk about it openly.   One man who can is Ian Lowes, , the gravediggers’ GMB convenor at the time and still a union activist. He defends the strike. “It was ‘enough is enough’ by low-paid workers who were treated like dogs.” But he promises: “Never again.” The diggers’ down-shovels was a long time coming. Denis Healey, Labour’s Iron Chancellor, decreed a % pay rise limit for all workers in summer . At a secret meeting that autumn in his Sussex farmhouse, TUC leaders – among them David Basnett, leader of the cemetery workers’ union – warned him that, after years of wage restraint, they could not hold their members back.   Pay curbs were rejected at Labour’s annual conference, and the floodgates opened when striking Ford workers won a % pay rise. A tanker drivers’ walkout triggered a national fuel emergency before % increases were conceded. Public service unions swtly took up the cudgels and, on January , , staged a National Day of Action in support of a pound-a-week minimum wage, practically double the gravediggers’ money. In numbers, this was the biggest stoppage since the General Strike of . Eventually, the year lost ,, working days to stoppages. Stre came to Merseyside when GMB shop stewards representing , workers employed by Liverpool City Council met to plan a follow-up. “The national leaders had lost control,” says Ian. “So we decided to go for selective action, bringing out key workers and putting a financial levy on everybody . Binmen carried on working but we closed tips, so the rubbish piled up.”   In the Parks and Gardens department, eight crematorium workers and about  gravediggers were called out on a show of hands. This was the s, before Tory labour laws demanded pre-strike secret ballots. The walkout was solid. Pickets weren’t needed at the city’s big sites like Allerton Cemetery – where we’re speaking today – and the adjoining Springwood Crematorium. The levy meant the strikers enjoyed virtual take-home pay. It could have gone on indefinitely, like some of the walkouts by council workers that left London’s Leicester Square a mountain of uncollected refuse, and half the country’s hospitals on emergency admissions only as NHS manual workers joined the dispute.   Leaders of the Liberal-run city council begged the men to go back, the chief executive anticipating media malice with a plea, “Even in war they stop to bury the dead”. An irate GMB official came to Liverpool and ordered the men resume work, prompting a predictable Scouse raspberry. Hostility went off the Richter scale. Inevitably, Tory leader Margaret Thatcher condemned the walkout, sensing electoral opportunity. In the Commons, Anthony Steen, Tory MP for Liverpool Wavertree, called it “repugnant, an outrage to human decency” causing great personal distress to the bereaved. Some  bodies were awaiting burial or cremation, embalmed and stored in a disused factory in Speke, he told MPs. “This strike offends against the dignity of man, and is a horrying example of man’s indference and inhumanity to the dead,” he declared.  This was the MP later to find fame for claiming pound, expenses for his country home in Devon, where he moved after losing his Scouse seat. And a vicar shared this apocalyptic vision: “When gravediggers will allow corpses to mount up rather than carry out their duty, I detect the undermshyining of the whole structure of society.” Duty  For the men it was a job of work, carried out for -odd quid a week in all weathers, without protective clothing. They were not even allowed into the canteen for their break. A dumper truck came round with the tea and they ate their snap round an open hole. Ian insists: “This was all about a group of low-paid people fighting to try to get a better deal. They had a right to withdraw their labour but, when they did, the consequences were terrible.” As working-class men in communities, it was obvious strikers’ identities would be known. One was attacked in a pub and taken to AE, where it is said he was left for hours by NHS staff, even though they were in dispute, too. One whose mother died is still not speaking to the family. There were threatening letters and verbal abuse. In fact, I understand some cremations were secretly taking place at Springwood of bodies that could not be embalmed. They were held in the evening, by unpaid volunteers. In the second week of the walkout, they gathered to take stock. Enough really was enough – of the strike. The action was hurting ordinary people, not the government. They voted to go back after  tumultuous days in the eye of a media storm. Propaganda damage had done its worst in this corner of militancy, but the wider dispute did not end. Council workers struck, and unofficial strikes by ambulance staff and other public service workers continued until late February, when % pay rises were granted and Healey signed a peace treaty with the TUC. As a show of political unity, it was too little, too late. Jim Callaghan had ducked a general election in September . Labour was then five points in the lead in opinion polls, but by the end of the Winter of Discontent the Tories were  ahead. They were helped by complacent Callaghan, who ed from a conference in the sunny Caribbean and didn’t quite say to reporters at Heathrow, “Crisis, what crisis ” But the headlines did, and that’s what mattered in a nation on the cusp of radical political change. “Britain Isn’t Working” ads and TV broadcasts for the May election showed footage of rubbish piled in the streets, picketed hospitals and locked cemeteries. Swept into power on an anti-union ticket, Thatcher enacted laws that would have made the gravediggers’ dispute unlawful. Some say the unions dug their own grave. Does Ian, a one-time member of the hard-left Militant Tendency, think it could happen again  “In the last  years, this is the only time there has been a dispute in the cemeteries of Liverpool. There have been issues, but they have been resolved without strike action. My answer is no.” That might come as a relief to the  workers who still tend the city’s six cemeteries. And at least they can now sup tea in the canteen. One of the Class of  declined to talk to the Mirror, so these words may have to be the epitaph for the revolt of the Liverpool gravediggers.

title: half countrys bus routes could
story: NewsHalf of the countrys bus routes could be scrapped due to funding crisisThousands of services subsidised by councils are in danger because the funding may have to be erted whereShareCommentsByMark Ellis:,  FEB NewsA row of buses "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNearly half of bus routes are at risk of being scrapped due to a funding crisis, town halls warn as they battle Tory austerity. The , services which councils subsidise are in danger because the money may have to be erted to deal with a poundmillion funding shortfall for the free bus pass scheme. Town hall leaders said it could mean “older people having a free bus pass but no bus to travel on”. Hundreds of thousands of people could lose the bus services they rely on as cash-strapped councils continue to be squeezed.  Local authority leaders are warning that almost half of bus routes are at risk of being scrapped. It stems from local authorities facing an annual poundmillion fundshying gap for the free bus pass scheme for disabled people and over-s. Councils in England say this shortfall means they cannot spend as much on the roughly , bus services they subsidise, putting them at risk. These subsidised routes make up % of the total number. Leaders want the Government to reinstate the full fundshying of the free bus pass scheme. Martin Tett, Local Government Association transport spokesman, said: “Properly funding [it] is essentialthe Government wants councils to be able to maintain our essential bus services. “If this is not addressed... it could lead to older people having a free bus pass but no bus to travel on.”Shadow Transport Secretary Andy McDonald said the poundmillshyion shortfall “shows the utter contempt the [Tories] have for the mode of public transport used by mostordinary people”.Town halls are obliged to pay for the bus pass scheme but are having to cope with much less cash from central government. The Department for Transport said it helps councils subsidise bus services through poundmillion worth of investment. It added there is a further poundbillion for the free bus pass scheme.
