title: darwins-handwritten-origin-of-the-species-notes-barred-from-leaving-uk
story: A page from Charles Darwins handwritten draft of On The Origin of Species has been stopped from leaving by Michael Ellis, the UK minister for arts, in the hope that a British institution will purchase the papers.The page from On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Le is valued at pound,.It includes corrections and shows Darwinrsquos reworking, and was sold at Sotherbys auction house last year.Some of the text dfers substantially from what was eventually published in the first edition of the book.Two other fragments of his writing have also been barred, for a limited period, from leaving the country.Mr Ellis said: "Charles Darwin is one of the most influential figures in history and these pieces represent a direct and physical connection to how he developed his pioneering work."These handwritten and personally signed pieces create an incredibly powerful impression that simply could not be achieved from looking at a digital version or even a published copy."That is why it is right that we do what we can to preserve these valuable items for the nation.Published in , On the Origin of Species is widely regarded as the foundation of evolutionary biology.Written at Down House, the page, number , forms part of his conclusion for Chapter  which focuses on hybridism and is the only substantial part of the chapter to survive.The decision to defer the export licences follows a recommendation by the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest , which is administered by The Arts Council.They made their recommendation on the grounds that due to Darwinrsquos great signicance and the impact of his work on humanity, the departure of the few pages that remain in private hands would be a "misfortune."Peter Barber, a member of the RCEWA, said: "Handwritten drafts of Charles Darwinrsquos books are of the greatest rarity."The few surviving sheets, touched by and written on by him, with evidence of pauses for contemplation, or spurts reflecting the rapid flow of thought, bring one closer to the man and his process of creation than perhaps anything ."The fragments under threat of export are particularly important."They show how Darwin revised his texts, pinning successive revisions onto sheets containing an earlier draft."One fragment comes from his best-known work and indeed includes the words lsquonatural selectionrsquo."But the other two fragments, from his Expression of the Emotions of Man and Animals, are perhaps even more important."Though less well-known than On the Origin of the Species this book, among the earliest works on behavioural psychology, greatly influenced Sigmund Freud. One of these fragments, for instance contains the observation that lsquoEveryone protects himself when falling to the ground by extending his armsrsquo."The nation has the chance to save revealing and intimate fragments of two works which, directly or indirectly, have shaped and continue to shape the modern world."The decision on the export licence application for the pages will be deferred until  May.

title: headteachers-working-in-more-than-one-school-in-scotland-up-64-in-seven-years
story: A Freedom of Informationrequest obtained by TES Scotland indicates that between  and ,  headteachers started working in multiple schools, representing a total of .The total number of headteachers working in the country also fell during that period, from , to ,.Primary school headteachers made up the majority of those working in more than one school, with  in  - up by  on the figure for .The figures also indicate that the greatest increases were seen in headteachers who worked at schools considered to be either accessible rural or remote rural.The statistics outlined in the FOI were documented in a report produced by the Scottish Governments Working Group on Headteacher Recruitment in September .The report made recommendations to work to improve the attractiveness of headteacher jobs.It stated: "Scotland is not alone in encountering issues in respect of headteacher recruitment."The apparent reduction in the attractiveness of the role of headteacher is a complex societal issue the solutions to which are, in some cases, beyond the control of the Working Group and the Scottish education system itself."However, this report and its recommendations represent a clear attempt by a range of key partners to take shared action to increase the attractiveness of the role and increase the number of teachers willing to undertake a headship role".Labour Education spokesman Iain Gray said that budget cuts and dficulties in bringing people into the teaching profession had created the problem.Mr Gray said: "The growing practice of schools having to share head teachers is just one more consequence of the SNPs mismanagement of our schools."The combination of a recruitment crisis and a poundm cut to school budgets is what lies behind this development. It can only reduce the effectiveness of leadership in our schools."While John Swinney sounds off about empowering headteachers, this is the reality on the frontline of his failure to protect schools."

title: the-junior-club-which-outclasses-football-giants
story: One hundred and ten years ago a local landowner donated what had been a copse.His name was Richard Wogan Talbot, fth Baron of Malahide. He gave Auchinleck its unusual name, Talbot, or Bot, and the Beechwood Park ground it has played in ever since.The ground did not see much success for its first four decades. Late in World War Two, German prisoners of war helped fix up the club house.Then in , Talbot won its first Scottish Junior Cup. That got the community excited. The following year thousands of tonnes of pit slag was moved to Beechwood to beef up the terrace for the visit of rivals Irvine Meadow in the Scottish Cup.Some , people watched that game, an all-time record. It had taken  men and  trucks to move , tons of slag to Beechwood. Volunteering was to become a huge club tradition.There followed, alas, lean years. Auchinleck struggled throughout the s, once suffering an - defeat to arch-rivals from neighbouring pit village Cumnock. Its pavilion burned down in  after a spate of vandalisms.The community rallied around and new blood was brought in to the club. In  it won the Junior Cup again, beginning a run of  victories, including in .A new stand was put up - or rather an old one bought from Hamilton Academical- by . Volunteers did much off the work.Talbot are no strangers to their next opponents, Hearts. Their last big Scottish Cup run, in , ended after the Edinburgh side scored a th minute winner. Can Auchinleck once again show their class

title: how-talbot-holds-auchinleck-together
story: "There is no better sight in the whole world to wake up to," declares George as Carole lovingly rolls her eyes and grins in support. "Every day I think that."Fans do not come more loyal than George, a -year-old bus driver. And its a trait Carole likes. "Id never miss a game, home or away," he grins from under a hat emblazoned with the Talbot shield. What would have to happen for him not to go and see his team  "Dead," butts in Carole, . George, laughing at himself, admits escaping weddings to watch Auchinleck.:The Junior club which outclasses football giantsTheir semi, on Beechwood Avenue, sits just opposite the Talbot clubhouse. On their gate, in careful metalwork, is another shield, above their door, two flagstaffs.Carole Palmer at her front gate, picture by Colin MearnsBut the Palmers are not the only family to go full black and gold, the Talbot colours. Much of town has. Along its Main Street, the last few shops and pubs have put up flags and bunting. Why Auchinleck, a junior club, has made it in to the fth round of the senior Scottish Cup. After slaying Ayr United, the professional team from its county town  miles away, they are off to Edinburgh, to challenge premiership giants Hearts.This weekend at least  buses will leave the former pit village for the capital. Some  tickets have been sold. That is one for every second resident of the town.George and Carole Palmer and their daughter Karen"Everybody is hyper," says George. "The town feels great."Things are not usually easy in Auchinleck.AuchinleckThe coal mines - the very reason for its existence - are closed, their remnants now post-industrial tourist attractions. The old shops, the Co-Ops butchers and haberdashery stores, went decades ago, replaced, eventually, by a Tesco on the towns edge. Unemployment here in East Ayrshire is twice the national average.Soon the secondary school will shut, to be merged in to a new campus in neighbouring Cumnock. There is no cafe in the town centre open in an afternoon.Auchinleck is losing all of the little focal points that cement a community. Except Talbot. Football binds this place together, winning football, that is.Beechwood ParkTalbot may not play in the big leagues. But that means it is used to success and crowds of what would seem an impossible size for the community. Beechwood Park has a bigger capacity, around , standing, than Auchinleck has a population. George caught the Bot bug from his dad .:The Junior club which outclasses football giantsSo did Iain Wilson. His father, Alec, like oh-so-many men in the village, was a miner, a Communist who was a steward down one of Ayrshires last pits. Iain, , is keeping his head warm with a gringo green military cap, a red star stitched on its front. Family holidays, explains, were bus trips to the other side of the Iron Curtain.Iain WilsonForget the Cold War. In much of western Scotland it was football which ided towns and cities. Not in Auchinleck. Here the game brings people together. On the stands, explains Mr Wilson, politics and religion, is forgotten. So, sometimes are local sporting rivalries."My girlfriend Susan is an Ayr fan," says Iain. "She stood in in the Talbot end. She would probably say Talbot is her wee team.Iain, a former health worker, admits he has a big team, Celtic. What would happenAuchinleck played Celtic  Who would he support. "Talbot, of course," he says.This - for Auchinleck folk - is key. The spirit of a mining community - when your colleague always had to have your back, regardless of politics, religion or background - lives on in sport."You talk about that Rangers and Celtic thing," explains Iain. "They all used to work together, now they play together and they drink together - there are no Rangers or Celtic pubs - and they watch Talbot together."This community pride has rubbed off on the club. "We dont get the best players because we pay the most money, "Iain says. "The players are there because they want to be. They have kept themselves at the top of the game by the way they have been run."Success is not new. "The main thing for this club is the league and the junior cup," Iain says. "Up till this season people were not that enamoured about playing with the big clubs. It took a wee bit away from the junior cup. This season has an amazing run. It has given the club an exposure you cannot buy."Iain has his whole route on the "lang whang" - the historic A from Ayr to Edinburgh - planned for Sundays match.Rab Cross, picture by Colin MearnsRab Cross, , is all set too. Hes nursing a Tennants at the Market Inn, a Bot scarf round his neck and a Rangers shirt on his back. "I am a season ticket holder for both clubs," he says, making a distinction between senior and junior. Rab, a ed salesman, has been going to see both teams for decades. Talbots glory years, however, came when he was an adult.On the Market Inns wall is a wood plaque with each off the clubs dozen Junior Cup titles. First, , then all the rest since . Below is the legend, The Real Madrid of the Juniors and the curious phrase "Eeka Peeka Pukka Po". This, explains Rab, comes from a s deaf fan who could not quite manage to sing "Well support you ever more." Instead of mocking or excluding the supporter, the crowd adopted his version.Behind the bar is landlord John Lyle,  and born and bred in Auchinleck and self-confessed "Talbot diehard". In pride of place, among his best spirits, is a little wooden mascot, called Eeka Peeka Pukka Po.Do any of his customers not support the team  He laughs. "All of the lads are supporters. The club is the backbone of the town. It is all we have. If it wasnt for Talbot, we would not be on the map."John Lyle, picture by Colin MearnsTalbot preserves the spirit of a town, says councillorNEIL McGhee is, he says, an "interlouper". The now councillor flit to Auchinleck half a century ago. The son of a Prestwick miner, he had come for the dancing. And he stayed for a girl, his now we Jane.As he walks down his "new" homes Main Street, the -year-old strokes the sandstone walls of one of its Victorian buildings. "Its lost its sparkle," Neil says. Hes talking about the building material, which would once have shined on a wet day. But he might as well mean the whole town."We have a terrible problem with apathy," he says. "People, especially young people have no hope. There are so few jobs. If only they would improve the roads or help bring some industry, some light industry, to the town."People talk a lot about austerity. Well, we have had it for  years, ever since the mines closed."Neil, in a black Auchinleck Talbot windcheater, is pointing out where there used to be shops in the towns heyday.When most people think of poverty or unemployment, reckons Neil, their minds turn to big cities and towns. And it is big cities and towns, he argues, that get the resources to fight deprivation.: Auchinleck manager urges team to stay focused"Its hidden around here, the poverty," he says. "Its forgotten. But I really worry about the young people. I worry about their mental health, that some of them give up."This is where football comes in.Shops decorated in buntingEverybody Neil passes says hello. The last few businesses on the street have bunting to match his jacket. Austerity aside, the mood in Auchinleck is good."The place is buzzing with excitement and expectation of another victory, a surprise victory," he says. "The aspiration for many people is not very high and this game is one of the rare occasions when they get to be enjoy le without the worries of poverty."We are looking forward to a wonderful weekend and we will enjoy it regardless of the result."Neil McGheeNeil has been going to the football every since he arrived in the town. He has stood with the same friends for  years. He remembers losing a bet on the street when the Bot went down - in the late s.The club was not thriving when coal was. In fact, its biggest spells of success only came after the  strike that was the beginning of the end for Scottish mining.The secret of Talbots rise  Good management at a club run by its fans, reckons Neil. "We are a small community and we are grateful to the committee for the long, long history they have of victory in junior cups and the west of Scotland league," he says. They are key to keeping the spirit of the village alive and we cant praise them highly enough because they work non-stop and very hard."Beechwoord Park, by Colin Mearns

title: craig ascends bennachie 100 times
story: A Kemnay man ascended Bennachie  times in just one year.Craig Thomson completed the achievement on Sunday, December , .His friend, Ross Henderson, joined Craig on the milestone expedition.Ross said: “I met Craig back in  and a few months after, he spoke about wanting to do Bennachie  times in a year.“The main motivation behind this was the memory of a friend of his, Malcolm, who died of Neuofibromatosis.“Malcolm succombed to the condition shortly after he and Craig had completed an ascent of Bennachie so it is entirely fitting that he should complete such a challenge.”“I quite often saw Craig’s car heading out towards Bennachie on many an occasion, sometimes when it was dark.“I did join him on a few expeditions out on the hill, one of them we timed well as we ed to the car park when it was dusky.“I hadn’t heard much from Craig until a few days before Christmas when he sent me a text askingI wanted to join him for the th ascent.“On the day a few of us met up at the back of Bennachie car park, there were  of us and three dogs so an excellent turnout.“He handed us all a program for the day which contained a written discription of his previous ascents and how he had built up to the full .“In  he managed  and in  he reached  and then stopped counting as it was getting late in the year.”The group set off and after an hour or so they had reached the summit of Oxen Craig, Bennachie’s highest peak.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: nominations wanted for community council
story: Nominations are being sought to fill  vacancies on Bennachie Community Council.Ideally the Community Council is looking for representation from the settlements of Chapel of Garioch, Culsalmond, Insch, Oyne, Premnay and Rayne.Completed forms must be ed by  pm on Monday, March .An election will only take place on Tuesday, March from . pm and . pm at Insch Institute,nominees exceed the vacancies.The community council’s meeting following the election is due to take place on Monday  March  in the Insch Institute.Nomination forms are now available to collect from the Garioch Area Office in Gordon House on Blackhall Road, Inverurie or email garioch@aberdeenshire.gov.uk.Forms are also available from the Community Council by emailing bennachiecc@outlook.Forms can also be found locally in N S Wilson, Chemist, Insch.For further information about the vacancies please email Alison Cumming Alison.cumming@aberdeenshire.gov.uk or call  .Further information on community councils can be found online here or visit wwwmunitycouncils.scot.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Last years top price animal, a champion heer, sold for #,"  Strong entry of calves for Spring Show viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: to move or not to move that is the brexit question
story: Should people hold off putting those for sale signs up until the summer To move or not to move A study by the HomeOwners Alliance found that just  per centof people said their decision to stay where they are was based on concerns over Brexit, with more popular answers relating to lack of suitable homes and property prices.Russell Quirk, founded and CEO of hybrid estate agent Emoov said:ldquoThis research shows that Brexit isnrsquot the driving factor behind many UK home sellers looking to move or stay put and while we have seen the market slow due to the uncertain future of our partnership with the EU, the market is showing positive signs of recovery across the board.ldquoWhile this may strengthen once a Brexit deal is finalised there is no guarantee as to the outcome, and so those looking to sell should rest assured that now is as good a time as any to sell their home and later might not necessarily be better.Property commentator and buying agent Henry Pryor told the HomeOwners Alliance that he didnrsquot think that Brexit would have an impact straight away.ldquoJust like New Years Eve  when people wonderedplanes would fall out of the sky ortheir microwave would stop working because of the Millennium Bug I expect that March  will have a similar effect.ldquoWho seriously lsquoknowsrsquo what the impact of our actual orce from Europe will be ldquoThe three Drsquos will continue to provide a supply of sellers over the next year ndash death, debt and orce wonrsquot wait for Mrs May and Co to sort this out but there will be far fewer buyers who lsquomustrsquo purchase.ldquoAs a professional buyer, I am expecting to be especially busy as the more squeamish buyers ask for help making what in more normal times might be considered insulting offers. Brexiteers may claim that like other lsquoProject Fearrsquo predictions the anticipated damage to house prices has not been felt but I suspect they will be a bit more muted in a years time.If the Government negotiates a deal with the EU before March nothing will change until December , .The overriding answer seems to be that there is too much uncertainty at the moment soyou feel it is the right time to move, do it.Read more: Should I renew my EHIC card or will Brexit make it invalid data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.cumbernauld-news webimage ..! title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Saturday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Saturday  Feb  : AM

story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. Representatives from Stagecoach will also be present to hear feedback on the services provided on the island.Greig Mackay, deputy director for Bus Users Scotland said: “We are looking forward to ing to Orkney to hear the views of the bus passengers. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . We are keen to hear what worked and what didn’t last year to help us shape our plans for .”If you can’t make the events you can still provide feedback to yourbusmatters@bususers.org.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney youth conference takes place
story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. title: power cable fault results in rackwick work
story: A faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, has resulted in work being carried out at Rackwick Bay in Hoy.A Scottish and Southern Energy Networks spokesman said: “SSEN can confirm there is a network fault affecting one of the two electricity distribution cables that connect Orkney to the Scottish mainland. Following a fault investigation process, damage has been located to a section of the Pentland Firth East cable near the shore at Rackwick Bay, Hoy.“There is no impact to customer supplies on Orkney as a result of the fault and contingency measures are in place, including the potential operation of the backup power station at Kirkwall, supported by mobile generation sets, to ensure a safe and secure supply of electricity for customers.“SSEN is committed to ing the network to normal operation as soon as possible and has instigated a repair plan. Following the receipt of the necessary permissions from statutory authorities late last week, work to undertake a sectional cable replacement is now under way.#The statement added: #It is expected this work, which will be contingent on tidal flows and weather conditions, will be complete early next week, with the line re-energised shortly after.“As part of SSEN’s subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is already at an advanced stage of development, with cable installation and commissioning currently due to take place in autumn next year.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: views sought on cursiter quarry expansion plans
story: Orkney Islands Council is providing a further opportunity for the public to view and comment on plans to expand Cursiter Quarry in Firth.The Council is due to submit a planning application for the long-term development of Cursiter Quarry in Firth this Spring.As part of a -phased expansion plan designed to secure additional reserves the quarry could increase in size over the next three decades expanding into neighbouring fields. The planning application also covers landscaping and future restoration of the site.The application process is being handled by consultants AECOM.The council-owned quarry currently supplies stone and aggregate materials for Council roads and building projects as well as the local construction industry.  It extracts Devonian Flagstone which is highly suited to a range of crushed aggregate products, in particular as roadstone and aggregates, used for producing asphalt for road construction and maintenance, with the quarry being the only active producer of asphalt in Orkney.The activity at the quarry generates an income for the Council which is reinvested to provide and protect some of the vital services we provide in Orkney.The current quarry area is heading towards the end of its use and an expansion would safeguard supply of materials. Current output ranges between , and , tonnes of rock per year andapproved, the ha expansion will release approximately  million tonnes of additional resources, sufficient for another  years of production.Full details are available on the Council website at http:www.orkney.gov.uk Council C long-term-development-of-cursiter-quarry-in-firth.htmPersons wishing to provide comments on the proposed development can do so by writing to AECOM at fraser.blackwood@aecom or by post to Fraser Blackwood, APEX ,  Haymarket Terrace, Edinburgh, EH HD by  February .OIC says that, at this stage, comments made to Aecom are for the purposes of assisting with the scheme design and EIA process and as such are not representations to the Planning Authority. title: Black Isle cafes Brexit talk ban raises cash for worthy cause
story: The tongue-in-cheek bid to banish the Brexit blues at Rosemarkie Beach Cafeacute over the festive season saw customers warned theyrsquod face a pound finethey so much as mentioned a word seldom out of the headlines lately.Philip Eley, the long-standing cafeacute manager, explained. ldquoItrsquos just grim. People are so depressed. Folk come to the beach to get away from all those headlines about what the idiots in Westminster are up to, but it only takes one person to mention the B-word to ruin everyone rsquos bacon roll.Customers warmed to the idea and willingly dropped contributions in the bucket during visits to the Black Isle beauty spot.Mr Eleyrsquos partner, Verity Walker, made good on a promise to donate takings from the offbeat bucket collection to the Maggiersquos Highlands cancer care centre at Raigmore Hospital. It was gratefully accepted by fundraising manager David Walker, who is no relation. Ms Walker said: ldquoWe finally got the donations bucket and collecting can to the Maggiersquos Centre at Raigmore ndash they were quite heavy as we kept them on the counter a bit longer and you just kept on giving!ldquoMaggiersquos has helped a number of cafeacute customers and staff. They exist to support those who are affected by cancer, but that includes the families of those diagnosed. If you have never been in, please go and visit, itrsquos a lovely calm space amid the hustle and bustle of Raigmore.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Black Isle festival issues tongue in cheek invite to ex Oasis star
story: The announcement last week that Noel Gallagher and his High Flying Birds will take to the stage in Inverness on June  was greeted with delight by fans of the multimillion-selling star who shot to fame as the creative force behind Oasis.Less thrilled about the timing of the Bught Park gig, organised by Live in the City and boasting support from Razorlight and Neon Waltz, were the organisers of the Black Isle-based Woodzstock, scheduled to take place on the same date in an outdoor adventure park near Tore, just a few miles from Gallaghers headline-grabbing gig.Woodzstock organisers Charlotte and Dave Elliott admit they were rocked ndash and not in a good way ndash when they learned of the clash. Within hours they rallied with a defiant show must go on plan ndash to invite Gallagher to perform at their intimate venue ahead of his own show in the Highland capital.Charlotte said: "Were excited that big names like Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds are coming to the Highlands andwe werent holding our festival on the same day we would have loved to see them play. We didnt want to miss him so were inviting Noel to come along and play a few tunes at Woodzstock before his gig in Inverness."She added: "We know it a long shot! Were asking the public to help us by posting online sharing the hashtag #GetNoeltoWoodz"Now entering its third year, Woodzstock has grown year on year with more bands, festival-goers and local businesses, including food producers, artists and performers, sound engineers and local charities, benefiting.Charlotte said: "This year promises to the best Woodzstock yet, we have some fantastic bands already booked, amazing locally sourced food and drink and activities running for the kids. An appearance from Noel would be amazing. We hope our invitation reaches him and he knows our stage will be ready for him".No one from Live in the City was available for comment on the fixture clash. Mr Gallagher could not be reached for comment.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Easter Ross gymnastics club storms to national success

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted on strike action
story: A BALLOT that could lead to strike action resulting in disruption to flights across the Highlands is due to open next week.The Prospect union confirmed it is going ahead with the ballot of air traffic control members at Highlands and islands airports in a dispute over pay with their employers, Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd .The ballot will run from February  to March  andmembers back industrial action, a series of one-day strikes could start on April  and run throughout the summer.As well as affecting Inverness Airport operations could also be disruptedat Benbecula, Dundee, Kirkwall, Stornoway, Sumburgh and Wick John OGroats.Members are also being askedthey wish to take action short of an all-out strike that could include working to rosters an overtime ban and refusing extensions to airport opening hours for non-medical flights.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoMembers do not wish to take this action but have been forced into this position by the refusal of ministers to engage with the issue of air traffic controllersrsquo pay.Hial is owned by the Scottish Government which last week said all staff had been given a pay rise which was a ldquosignicant improvement on previous years.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: New homes planned for Dingwall
story: DINGWALL moved a step closer to getting  new homes after the Ross and Cromarty area committee agreed an infrastructure investment ldquounlocking the possibility of the development.But councillors were at odds over the plans with some considering them a sop in lieu of the  homes earmarked for the town since  while others said it was a ldquopositive move in a high pressure area for housing demand.The original plan was based on the delivery of the Kinnairdie Link Roadproject ndash expected to unleash millions in inward investment. It was due to start its final phase of construction this year but it was axed from the councilrsquos capital programme in last yearrsquos budget.Then in March, funding for transport improvements in Dingwall was found to enable some housing development to take place prior to the commencement of the KLR.A transport study and modelling work considered the impact of ious levels of development in the town and improvements will include work at the Bridgend Avenue Junction and Docharty Road Junction as well as traffic signal works at Mart Road Junction. Proposals for walking and cycling improvements and traffic management measures will also be brought forward to enhance active travel facilities in the town.Dingwall and Seaforth councillor Graham Mackenzie said: ldquoIt would be tempting to see it as a good news story for Dingwall. That is not the case. Had we been given what we were promised in an earlier iteration of the capital plan we could be releasing up to  houses for development instead of around ."Instead the KLR was taken out of the capital plan even though the first phase of the project had already started. If Dingwall is to grow and provide the range of housing which is required, the KLR must be moved up the list of priorities. This project needs to be reinstated.Fellow ward councillor Angela Maclean insisted the deal was good news. She said: ldquoWe as councillors have a leadership role and it is up to us to be helping our communities to move forward and this report has examples of when officers have looked for solutions to get round some of the fact that we donrsquot have all the money we would like."Whether it is through the infrastructure road plans or capital fund we are going to try and move forward with these houses in Dingwall, because Dingwall is a pressurised area ndash this is a positive move because we donrsquot have enough houses in Dingwall.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Old office goes back on market in Dingwall
story: The former assessorrsquos office in Ferry Road, which adjoins the old Sherf Court, dates back to .A category B listed commercial property it was on the market a year ago and it was thought a buyer had been found. But the sale fell through and the property is again up for sale with offers over pound, invited.Originally built as a police station, the property has a colourful history with its location next to the courthouse.The sherf court was closed by the Scottish Court Service in January  as part of a cost-cutting and restructuring scheme.The following year the property was sold and converted into a private dwelling. The former police station been used for many years by Highland Council as offices for the assessor.The assessor is responsible for assigning a value to properties for tax purposes.Because it was a commercial property it is not necessary to provide a survey of the building to potential buyers.It is in a mix of modern and traditional residential properties close to the town centre on Ferry Road.Of stone and slate construction it comprises three rooms on the ground floor and four rooms on the first floor.A council spokesman said the property requires extensive work, but it has its own entrance and parking to the front of the property.The closing date set for offers is March , .Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: People power sees safety measures considered for Tain junctions at last
story: HOPES are high that action will finally now be taken at two of the most dangerous road junctions in Easter Ross following a string of accidents and near-misses.Concerns about Tainrsquos two main junctions with the A prompted campaigners to claim a failure by roads chiefs to act would ldquoinevitably lead to someone being killed.Tain and Easter Ross councillor Derek Louden was joined by politicians from across the political spectrum in flagging up concerns, among them local MP Jamie Stone who said he had ldquopersonally witnessed more smashes than I care to remember and that ldquothere is something terribly wrong here.Campaigners had suggested a iety of possible measures, including reducing the speed limit, changing the road layout and even the installation of roundabouts ndash but their pleas fell on deaf ears.However, Transport Scotlandrsquos new area road safety manager, Richard Perry, has told Cllr Louden draft proposals have now been drawn up following an analysis of collisions at the north and south junctions by trunk road operator BEAR Scotland.Short-term measures could include enhanced signage, improved surfacing and better road markings.In the medium term, improvements to the bell mouth radius of the south junction will be considered.The possibility of reducing the speed limit on the bypass section to mph will also be investigated, but this would require statutory processes and consultation.Mr Perry said the construction of a roundabout could be considered, but would require agreement on funding.Cllr Louden told the Journal he was delighted to hear safety could finally be improved at the dangerous junctions.He welcomed the widening of the exits to allow lorries and buses to get onto the A without having to use the central reservation.And he said he was pleased to see a commitment to holding a consultation on reducing the speed limit on the bypass ldquoso that when accidents do occur, they are less likely to be fatal.He said he hoped efforts would begin early this year, as suggested in the letter.An initial review by roads chiefs noted a disproportionate number of incidents with buses and heavy goods vehicles exiting the minor road to enter the A into the path of approaching vehicles and ldquoa small number of poorly judged overtaking manoeuvres through the A junction.Tain Community Council previously said that simply blaming driver error was ldquoa cop out which failed to tackle the issue of two dangerous junctions.It warned the roadrsquos inclusion on the NC made accidents more likely.What do you think  Email us title: Ross nurses lead the way
story: Chrissie Laneand Lucy Heycockentered the gruelling Strathpeffer -hour mountain bike challenge with the aim of encouraging some of their patients and colleagues to embrace new challenges and experiences.The annual event near Strathpeffer sees riders tackle freezing temperatures,  hours of darkness and mile upon mile of frozen forest tracks.The dynamic duo were delighted with a podium finish. Macmillan cancer consultant nurse Chrissie, from Culbokie, said: ldquoWe work every day with amazing people living with cancer and are trying to support them to be active outdoors which has huge proven benefits to their health and recovery.ldquoMaking small or big changes to the amount of moving your body does throughout the day have immense benefits for people living with cancer.Theyrsquore promoting everything from short walks and cycle rides to hillwalking.Chrissie added: ldquoThe reason why we took part in the event was to try to be role models for older woman to just give experiences a try. All it needs is a gritty frame of mind and a sense of humour and fun when situations are not so pleasant.Chrissie and advanced nurse colleague Lucy, from Muir of Ord, were delighted with a podium finish, coming in an extremely credible third in the competitionrsquos female pairs category.Both Chrissie and Lucy hope that their success shows that you can take up and enjoy exercise, even doing an event like the challenging Strathpuffer, at any age.Saturday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: Plenty of onlookers were already on the streets as the squad made its first procession of the day from Islesburgh Community Centre, past the galley shed on St Sunniva Street and on to the Toll Clock Shopping Centre.In the gloom, the ranks of the Jarl#s Squad looked the part wearing emerald green kirtles with dragon mots underneath simple brown leather breastplates embossed with the same mot. title: bringing shakespeare to a new generation
story: As well as staging the dark comedy a block of drama workshops are being put on to help the youngsters involved develop the skills needed to take part.The ethos behind the workshops is that they will show people that they need not be put off by Shakespeare and any notions that his work is #dficult, incomprehensible, archaic, intellectual#. In fact, his plays were written for the masses and the anniversary events will show participants how to get their tongue around some of the more unusual words and explain what they mean.This series of workshops are booked as a block and will allow participants to further develop their drama skills. They will culminate with a short sharing session for family and friends in the Mareel auditorium.Anyone aged between  and  can take part.The events are on Sundays th February and th March at the Garrison Theatre in Lerwick and on Sundays rd March and th March in Mareel. in Walls Community Garden. raquo..

title: halcro johnston welcomes comments from senior snp minister on ferry funding
story: Signs have emerged of a softening in the Scottish government#s approach to fair ferry funding, with one Tory MSP insisting a senior SNP colleague has given backing for a better deal on leline links.Isles councillors have been left frustrated by the Scottish government#s funding offer following its budget, not least because of a shortfall in ferry funding.Complaints have been made by island leaders that the funding settlement, agreed last year, does not meet the full costs of running the internal ferries in Orkney and in Shetland.In the Western Isles the costs are met by the Scottish government as part of Clyde and Hebridean ferry service contract.But Conservative MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston had highlighted a visit to Orkney by the SNP #s constitutional relations secretary, Mike Russell.Jamie Halcro JohnstonAccording to a news release dispatched on Thursday, Mr Russell told The Orcadian newspaper: “I can take that back, and I can say to my colleagues, look this is a big issue in Orkney, and obviously it needs a resolution”.Mr Halcro Johnston welcomed the cabinet secretary’s acknowledgement that a resolution was required and urged one to be brought forward.“I welcome news of Mike Russell’s comments on fair ferry funding, and I’m encouraged by the intervention of a senior SNP minister. As a representative for Argyll and Bute, Mr Russell clearly understands ferry issues rather better than some of his government colleagues.#It comes after the Scottish government agreed to alter its spending plans with support from the Scottish Greens.The Greens said the Scottish government had agreed to alter its spending plans in exchange for support in getting the budget through.SIC leader Steven Coutts told The Shetland Times on Thursday: #At the moment we#re still waiting to see the final full detail on the back of the deal that was done between the Green Party and the SNP. We need to see what the figures actually mean.#There#s still no commitment on full and fair ferry funding, and that#s something we#ll want to press the government and Green Party on.#..
